verses.text: Jehoshaphat, his son, became king in his place and strengthened himself against Israel.
verses.comment: Jehoshaphat refers to the son of Asa, confirming the transition of kingship.

verses.text: He stationed troops in all the fortified cities of Judah, and he placed garrisons throughout the land of Judah and in the cities of Ephraim that his father Asa had conquered.
verses.comment: The mention of Ephraim connects to Asa's previous conquest.

verses.text: The LORD was with Jehoshaphat because he walked in the earlier ways of his ancestor David and did not seek the Baals.
verses.comment: The phrase 'earlier ways' refers to David's faithfulness before his later failings.

verses.text: Instead, he sought the God of his father and followed His commandments, and did not act as Israel did.
verses.comment: Israel here refers to the northern kingdom, which had turned from God.

verses.text: So the LORD established the kingdom in his hand. All Judah brought gifts to Jehoshaphat, and he had great riches and honor.
verses.comment: The gifts are tributes expressing submission to Jehoshaphat's rule.

verses.text: His heart was lifted up in the ways of the LORD; he even removed the high places and Asherah poles from Judah.
verses.comment: High places and Asherim were sites of idol worship; 'lifted up' means he was fully committed.

verses.text: In the third year of his rule, he sent his officials—Ben-hail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah—to teach in the cities of Judah.
verses.comment: These officials had the responsibility of instructing the people in God's law.

verses.text: Joined with them were the Levites: Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tob-adonijah; and the priests Elishama and Jehoram.
verses.comment: The list includes both Levites and priests to show broad participation in teaching.

verses.text: They taught in Judah, carrying the Book of the Law of the LORD. They went throughout all the cities of Judah and taught the people.
verses.comment: Makes explicit that they taught from the Law, clarifying their method.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD fell on all the kingdoms around Judah, and they did not make war against Jehoshaphat.
verses.comment: Illustrates divine protection over Judah due to Jehoshaphat's faithfulness.

verses.text: Some of the Philistines brought Jehoshaphat gifts and silver as tribute, and the Arabs brought him flocks—seven thousand seven hundred rams and seven thousand seven hundred goats.
verses.comment: Numbers are kept literal; details about tribute reflect regional relationships.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat became increasingly powerful. He built fortresses and store cities in Judah.
verses.comment: Store cities are for supplies, fortresses for military strength.

verses.text: He had a large supply of provisions in the cities of Judah and men of war, mighty warriors, in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The division between provisions and soldiers highlights preparedness for both peace and war.

verses.text: This was their muster by families: Of Judah, the commanders of thousands—Adnah the commander, and with him three hundred thousand mighty men of valor;
verses.comment: Muster means counted or registered for military service.

verses.text: Next to him was Jehohanan the commander, and with him two hundred and eighty thousand;
verses.comment: Listing continues showing the order of commanders.

verses.text: And next to him was Amasiah son of Zichri, who volunteered for the LORD; and with him two hundred thousand mighty men of valor.
verses.comment: Notes Amasiah's voluntary, or willing, service to God.

verses.text: Of Benjamin—Eliada, a mighty man of valor, and with him two hundred thousand men armed with bows and shields;
And next to him was Jehozabad, and with him one hundred and eighty thousand, prepared for war.
verses.comment: Lists Benjamin's military leadership and numbers.

verses.text: These were those who served the king, besides those he had stationed in the fortified cities throughout all Judah.
verses.comment: Distinguishes the central royal army from dispersed garrisons.
